reviews.review_text: My favorite  book. Helps  to understand the forces that shaped  the Balkan countries  from the Ottoman Turks  to the WW1.  I can recommend to  history buffs.
Gives a better understanding of the dynamics of the balkan region.
I gave up.  the prosewastoo difficult to follow -long, run-on sentences.

History is often passed down through books or stories. The bridge in Ivo Andrić’s novel The Bridge Over the Drina needs no history lesson, for it has been a witness to history over centuries in Višegrad in modern-day Bosnia and Herzegovina. Perhaps the only true constant is the solid presence of the bridge that links the novel’s stories across the centuries. Rather than relating the history of the town on cultural or societal level, Andrić paints a picture of the town throughout the 400-year span of the book through the lives of its inhabitants from the construction of the bridge under Ottoman rule to the departure of the Austro-Hungarians at the beginning of World War I.Andrić focuses more on the bridge and the changing lives of the town through short narratives. The result is a lack of real character development beyond short sketches of people’s lives, which often end tragically. However, this structure allows him to cover a greater time period than the typical novel, which provides more insight into the town’s history and the ways in which societal change impacts the lives of individuals. Though the book can be confusing at points due to Andrić’s jumps back and forth in the timeline, it still produces captivating snapshots of life in the Western Balkans throughout their occupation.
Central Europe has a complex history.  I really enjoyed reading this book.

I am new to this author and to the area of the World it describes. Andric skillfully spans three centuries of the bridge and its effect on the area and its peoples. A confluence of urban and rural and Turkey and Hungary and Austria, and Jew and Muslim and Christian.and various Balkan communities.A full plate indeed. All this interplay is masterfully crafted through a variety of individual and community stories. I read it in two sessions having to pause to reflect and consider so many issues that are raised. I have already recommended this to four friends. I wonder what I miss in translation,but I am glad to have read it. Double glad that read a book from apart of the world with which I was unfamiliar. Though from a time past I found many issues germane to our current time. Do yourself a favor and read it.

This is really nice collection of well written stories that provide historical, and cultural details about life in a Bosnian town during the various foreign occupations, and the bridge which served as the focal point of town activities, and the town's actual and metaphorical connection to the rest of Europe.

summary:
The Bridge on the Drina is a vivid depiction of the suffering history has imposed upon the people of Bosnia from the late 16th century to the beginning of World War I. As we seek to make sense of the current nightmare in this region, this remarkable, timely book serves as a reliable guide to its people and history.

"No better introduction to the study of Balkan and Ottoman history exists, nor do I know of any work of fiction that more persuasively introduces the reader to a civilization other than our own. It is an intellectual and emotional adventure to encounter the Ottoman world through Andric's pages in its grandiose beginning and at its tottering finale. It is, in short, a marvelous work, a masterpiece, and very much sui generis. . . . Andric's sensitive portrait of social change in distant Bosnia has revelatory force." William H. McNeill, from the introduction

Born in Bosnia, Ivo Andric (1892-1975) was a distinguished diplomat and novelist. He was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1961. His books include The Damned Yard: And Other Stories, and The Days of the Consuls.
